subject: Re: [junit] RE: organizing tests, and third party libraries

messageBody:
Seems to me that the ideal solution is for 3rd party library
creators to include their unit tests as part of their library.

This not only gives more credibility to the library but also
gives developers using the library a source for sample code.

I recently used junit for the first time on a smallish project.
The project was a kind of communications library. It was to
be used inhouse. I gave the code to the people that were
going to be using the library. I heard nothing from them. I
was worried that they weren't using the library. It turns out
that they didn't need me as I had junit tests and javadocs.
They didn't find a single bug (not that there isn't any) and
so had no issues.

John.

----Original Message Follows----
>Now I had a number of problems recently that I traced not to failure
>of my code to do what I thought it should do, but rather to
>discrepancies between the behavior of plain sockets and SSL sockets.
>In other words, the SSL libraries had bugs in them.[...]
>
>So then I thought maybe what I'm trying to do here isn't really Unit
>Testing. [...]
>
>In retrospect, I can come up with a characterization of the problem
>and say that I made certain assumptions about the behavior of the
>sockets API. Given that was the case, it would have been prudent of
>me to write (very simple) test cases that verify those assumptions,
>and run them on both plain and SSL sockets. These tests, of course,
>would be very simple, and wouldn't involve any of my product code.
>
>Presumably if I tested the assumptions correctly in both cases, then I
>wouldn't have to test my code in both of its configurations (since
>from its point of view it's not really doing anything different in the
>two different cases).
>
>Is this another form of testing ("Assumption Testing")? Or perhaps
>another way to look at it is that I'm a "customer" of the SSL library
>provider, and I need to have my own "Acceptance Test" of the
>functionality that I expect it to provide?

Your tests of a third-party API are your acceptance tests of that API. If
you give them to the maker of the API, they can be their unit tests or their
acceptance tests.

I have found testing a third-party library to be extremely valuable...
Whenever you get a new version of that third-party library, you can run all
your tests to see if the library makers have fixed known bugs, created new
bugs, or changed assumptions....

Once you are confident of the third-party library's functionality, you could
choose to use Mock objects in the production code unit tests, or continue to
use the actual library objects.
